turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You don't tell us how to run our investigation.  You got that?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You don't have an investigation without me.  You got that?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You know, I figure that's pretty much how these girl's feel just before they get it.  You think I'm right?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I wouldn't know.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: That's right.  I guess only the killer would know that.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: How'd you get in here?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: The door was open.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No it wasn't.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Of course it was.  Otherwise I'd be breaking and entering.  That's a felony.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You ever do any hunting, Peter?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I used to.  With my old man.  He taught me how to hunt and trap.  Trapping's a lot harder than most people think.  We used to go after Raccoons mostly. They'd get into our garbage, our fields.  When an animal can't live peacefully with those around it, it has to be destroyed.  But they're crafty little devils.  You see the trick is, you can put your trap down, but no Raccoon is going come near it unless you lay down the scent.  You ever smell Raccoon scent?  Smells like shit, but to a male Raccoon it smells just like pussy.  He'll walk right up to that trap, even though it don't look nothing like a Raccoon and stick his Goddam head right in it.  You know why?  Cause he can't help himself.  The scent drives him.  So, if you want to catch a Raccoon all you gotta do is figure out where he is -- lay down the scent -- and sooner or later he'll walk right into the trap.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What if he doesn't bite?  What if he's an exceptionally bright Raccoon?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Well then, you just gotta find out where he is -- and once you're sure where he is -- you shoot the fucker.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You got it on the board.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No, I need the original note.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: There's a photostat of the original on the wall.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He's not talking about himself.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Then what's he talking about?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If we knew that we'd know the answer to the riddle, wouldn't we?  He's telling us where he's going to kill tonight and we can't see it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Then let's narrow it down.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Homesearchers.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: We're interested in where you were from the time you left the auditorium until you got there.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I was at the beach.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You sure you weren't over on Pine Road?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm positive.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You're a lying bastard!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Fuck you!  I'm tired of your goddam accusations!  If you want to arrest me go ahead!  Otherwise back off.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: It's all a big game isn't it?  A sick, fuckin' game.  I don't know if there's two of you involved, or what -- but we're going to find out.  Last night you gave us just enough to send us to the wrong place.  It must've shocked the hell out to you when Frank walked in on Pine Road and you couldn't finish.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Yes you are.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Get off me!

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You set yourself up tonight when you attacked Kathy, you crazy fuck!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: The message!  I figured out--

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Sit down!

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: You want me to what?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I want you to feed every street in this grid into your computer.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: It'll take hours.  You can't make me do this.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You're right, I can't make you do it. Besides, you're probably gonna be too busy with the Franchise Tax Board anyway.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I gotta friend over there.  He was telling me things are kind of slow. So, I figured I'd give him a call, have him come down here and look through your records.  You know, give him something to do.

turns.speaker: WOMAN
turns.text: What's the first street?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Sorry to ruin your trip to the city, but we got a real nut on our hands, Frank.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Run it down.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Debi Rutlege.  Female.  Caucasian. Twenty four.  Worked over at the Four Oaks Hotel.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Local?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: No.  She just moved here last month from Portland.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: He's got an answer for everything, but he doesn't have an alibi.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You think he's dirty?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't know, but I think you're right. He's lying.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: We wouldn't want someone's death to interfere with your games.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What was your relationship with her?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Take it easy.  Both of you.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I'm sorry, this is just too convenient.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: No shit!

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Could someone this disturbed give the appearance of being normal?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Anything?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: The F.B.I. has nothing remotely similar to this guy.  I think he's a first- timer.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Check with the State.  If he's never killed outside of Washington the F.B.I. wouldn't have it.  Nolan?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You still having a problem with this?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Yeah, I am.  I think he's playing us. If I was a killer and the police were trying to make a case against me, what better why to draw them off than to put their attention on someone else?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: We've checked.  There's no one with the last name of Emma on the Island.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Maybe he's going to drug her?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: How is she?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: She's unconscious, but they think she's going to make it.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You alright?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I've seen a lot of things in my time on the job, but nothing like this. Yurilivich?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I was with him the whole time until I got the call at the hotel.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Sanderson?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I spoke to Jeremy.  He's watching Sanderson's kid.  Sanderson went out after the match and hasn't come back since.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Find him!  I want to talk to him.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's a voice modulator.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Ready for round two?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I've got a feeling we're going to go the distance with him.  Let him sweat for a little while.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: You should be an actor, Frank.  You looked like you were really mad.  The veins popping out on your neck was a really nice touch.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You weren't mad at him for picking up the phone?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Why does he call Sanderson?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: He's one of the best Chess players in the world.  Who better to play a game with?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Sending yourself anonymous notes in the mail is one thing -- but who called him today?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: I don't know.  Maybe there's two of them.  Maybe he hired some Wino to make the calls.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Maybe you're reaching a bit?  I think Sanderson should be in on this. There's a reason why the killer's calling him.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: A few people.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Did anyone stand out?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: What do you mean, stand out?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Did anyone look suspicious?  Think!

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Now that you mention it there was somebody who looked suspicious.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: What was suspicious about him?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: It doesn't make sense because we don't understand it.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: But a hundred men could move him.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Don't fuck with us!  Where did you go!

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: He was with me?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Remember eventually revenge is carefully...  Have you tired juxtaposing the words?

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Oh, c'mon.  We're not going to spend any more time on this crap, are we?  It doesn't mean anything.  It's Sanderson!

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: It isn't him.  Frank, you brought me in on this in the beginning because you wanted my opinion if he was capable of doing this.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: Jesus, you're sleeping with the guy. You've lost your perspective.  You can't possibly be unbiased.

turns.speaker: ANDY
turns.text: We'll find the evidence.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You couldn't find your dick in a wind storm!

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Hello, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Who is this?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Someone who's going to become an important part of your life.  I want to play a game with you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I haven't got time for this.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Hello, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Just a second.  Hello?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Very amateurish, Peter.  I'm surprised you would use such an obvious tactic.  I'm not an idiot!  Don't treat me as one!  I'll call you everyday... You get one minute, whether you put me on hold or talk is up to you!  Are you ready to play?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yes.  Why did you kill Debi Rutlege?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: To get your attention.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Did you know her?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: No, only the path she chose to travel.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: And -- what path is that?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: We all have paths to follow.  You hope yours will lead you to me.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why did you write remember on the wall?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: That's something you'll have to figure out for yourself.  Really, Peter, you can't expect me to answer such direct questions.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: You don't want to think and that's why I'll win!  I'm already two points ahead.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: I did another one last night.  You might have saved her, but you didn't want to play.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Where is she?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: You'll find her.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If you got something to say to me, just come out and say it!

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: I suppose you want to know where I'm going to kill tonight, Peter?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're not going to tell me that.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: "Wee Willie Winkie runs through the town.  Upstairs and downstairs in his nightgown.  Crawling through the window.  At the end of Miss Emma's street.  Her God has gone and left his home.  So her and I can meet."

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Do you know what I'm doing right now, Peter?  I'm looking at the name of the girl I'm going to kill tonight.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You know her?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Not really.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why her?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Because she's the type.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: But you said you didn't know her.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: I know what I said!  She looks just like...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Just like who?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: I really wish you'd stop trying to maneuver me.  I find it irritating, not to mention insulting.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm just trying to play the game.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: You're not playing very well.  There are clues all around you and you keep missing them.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: I'm sure there are other people who would be interested in what I have to say.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Then call them!

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Just for that no hint today.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Why are you doing this?  You must have some idea of the pain you're causing people.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Pain?  Pain is just a state of mind. It's something you learn to live with. I have.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: And you want these girls to feel your pain?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Please, I don't want to get into the psychological aspects of my actions. It would detract from the game.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: I couldn't say it any better than Huxley.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Huxley's quote also says, "his play is always fair and just."

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: So is mine, within the framework of my rules.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Have you any idea what the message is?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If it's so important, why don't you just tell me?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: I couldn't tell you that.  It would ruin the game.  Not that you're playing it very well.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You like to brag, don't you?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You heard me.  Why did you go out to the institute looking for her?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: What makes you think I was there?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I couldn't tell you that.  It would ruin the game.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: The game's almost over, Peter, and you're running out of time.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's you who's running out of time. You're starting to make mistakes now. You're wondering just how much I really know.  Just how close I'm getting? Well, I'm closer than you think, pal -- and I'm gonna nail your ass to the wall!

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Very nice speech, Peter.  Did you rehearse that, or was it impromptu?  There's an old wooden bench in the garden.  Next to it is a rock.  You'll find a message for you under it.  Let's see if you're as clever as you think you are.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Last night was very exciting, wasn't it?  Have you figured out what I'm doing?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're playing the Tarakoss opening.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Very good.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You're next move should have been e2- e3.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: I used a variation.  You should have anticipated that.  Have you figured out the message?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What word did you leave last night?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: The police haven't told you?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: They think that you and I are doing this together.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Interesting concept.  I hadn't thought of that.  If you think about how Anton Berger plays chess you might get it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm beginning to think it doesn't mean anything.  Remember eventually revenge- -

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: --you're hopeless!  You can't even read a sentence!  Didn't they teach you punctuation in school?  The game ends tonight!

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Hello, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You sonofabitch!

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Emotional?  I expected more from you.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: If you kill tonight and I'm in jail the police will know I'm innocent.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: By that time the game will be over.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I've figured out the message.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: No you haven't.  And even if you had it doesn't matter.  Who would you tell? The police don't believe you, and you've just used your only phone call.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Congratulations on your daring escape. You just missed me by a few seconds.  It's check, Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Let me speak to my daughter.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: She's in the other room.  I just wanted you to know she wasn't dead... yet. But it's time for her to die now.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Please... wait.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: The game's over.  You lost.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It's me you want.  Not her.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: No.  As usual you're wrong.  It is her I want.  Killing you would be easy. Living with the consequences of losing will be much more of a defeat.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: That wouldn't be very sporting. Remember Huxley?  "His play is always fair and just."

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: You're groping.  I have been fair. It's my move now.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'll give you anything you want. Anything!  Please!

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Don't beg, Peter.  She has to die.  I can't win unless she dies.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: I was thinking about leaving the phone line open so you could hear her die -- but I've decided it's better if you don't know exactly when I kill her. Good-bye Peter.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: No!  Wait!!

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I know where you are.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: Very good.  How did you know?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: The pipes.

turns.speaker: CALLER
turns.text: How'd you know I wouldn't be in the same room with her?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You told me.  When you called you said she was in the other room.  Drop the knife.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: This isn't going to help, David. You're mother's dead.  You can't undo it.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You don't understand.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes, I do.  I found your file.  I know what happened.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: They took away the game because of him. My father left and my mother...  There was so much blood... It covered everything.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I know, but this isn't going to bring her back.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Don't you see?  I had to make it right. I ignored my mother's crossing.  I sat with them all.  I held their hands.  I stroked their hair.  I was with them to the end.  I took away the blood.  I washed them.  Their crossing was peaceful.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I think your mother knows that now. Why don't you put the knife down.  Put it down, David.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Naw, it's all fixed.  I also loaded up a program that'll analyze your games three hundred percent faster.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Oh, I put a few games on for your daughter.  I hope you don't mind.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Sure.  We've got a modem line hooked up with the data base in New York.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Can we correlate data?  Look for specific things, like player's ages... stuff like that?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: No problem.  We're in.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Okay.  Run a search to see if there are any players with a rating above two thousand that live on the Island.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Nope.  Nothing.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Set up some pieces on the big board?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: D2-d4...  b1-c3... and c1-f4.  It's the number two variation of the Tarakoss opening.  David, can you bring up the tournament records for the last ten years.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Mister Sanderson, they'll be hundreds of thousands of games.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: Now what?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Have computer search for anyone that's used that opening against me.  There can't be more than a handful.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: There's three.  The first is 1983. Lionel Baines.  The Boston...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Never mind.  He died two years ago.

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: 1985.  Hans Korshaud.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: He's in his seventies and lives in Holland.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: New York.  1986.  Viktor Yurilivich.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Computers.  That's how you got into Homesearchers records.  You can get into anything.  But why?  Why?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: You still haven't figured it out, have you?   You think that I've put you through an ordeal.  My scars run so much deeper than yours.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What scars?

turns.speaker: DAVID
turns.text: The scars on your chest.  From where I stabbed you with my fountain pen.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: You might not have done it had you known.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You're damn right!  I'm a child psychologist and you send me into a room with someone who could be a murderer!

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: Would you mind keeping your voice down? I have guests.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Oh, well we wouldn't want to disturb your guests, would we?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: The police came to me for help.  What could I do?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You could have been honest with me for starters.  We work together.  I have to be able to trust you.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: I admit I handled it badly.  Sanderson wasn't going to talk to me... but you're young, attractive--

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: --the same type as the girl who got killed.  Jesus, Alan, the guy could be a psychopath.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: They asked who would be best suited for this and you--

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Don't patronize me!  You sent me into a potentially dangerous situation and didn't warn me!

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: It worked out alright, didn't it?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Fuck off!

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: Feeling better?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I just can't believe it.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: You don't want to believe it.  It's a normal reaction.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: How come the police never had a record of Sanderson before.  This doesn't come out of nowhere, there has to be a history.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: Kathy, please.  You're going to wear a hole in the carpet.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I'm just nervous.  Sorry.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: You're safe.  He wouldn't come here.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: He already did once.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Why did he?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: Why did he what?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Come here.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: He was watching you.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yeah -- that's what we've always thought -- but what if he wasn't?  What if I had nothing to do with the reason he came here?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR FULTON
turns.text: You're losing me.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You must be Erica.

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I'm Kathy.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Is your dad here?

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: He went down to the lobby for a minute. He should be right back.  Would you like come in?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: So, are you having a good time on the Island?

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: Not really.  It's pretty boring.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: That's only because you don't know where to go.  You like hiking?  Fishing?  Sailing?  What do you like?

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: Boys.

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: Do you like my dad?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: I know he really likes you.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: How do you know that?  Did he say something?

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: No... but I can tell.  A woman knows these things.

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: Okay.  Nice meeting you.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Nice meeting you.

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: Congratulations, dad.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: My cheering section.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What are you doing up?

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: I can't sleep.  My beds lumpy.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I see.  You forgot to bring you're night-light, didn't you?

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: That has nothing to do with it.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: You want to sleep in my bed tonight?

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Who told you that?

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: Mrs. Lutz.  She also told me that Mr. Lutz goes to a medium to try and contact great Grandmasters in the spirit world.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Has he gotten through to any?

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: No, but he did contact a dead parcheesi champion from Ohio.

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: What is it, dad?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Don't you have something you want to say to David?

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: Thanks, David.

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: You ready?

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: You told me you'd take me over to Seattle today.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: I'm sorry, honey, I can't.  Not today.

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: But you promised.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: It isn't Kathy.

turns.speaker: ERICA
turns.text: Who's Kathy?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Whaddaya got, Nolan?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Not much.  There's no sign of a break in.  I think she let him in.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How long has she been dead?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Six, eight hours tops.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Any sign of rape?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Not that I can see.  We'll know more once I get the lab reports back from Seattle.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: There's no blood.  Where's the fuckin' blood?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Bingo.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Anything?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Not much.  I don't think she was raped. There's no bruising, or any signs of trauma to the pelvic region -- and no trace of sperm which makes sense because she took a bath.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What about prints?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: No prints.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You mean, no prints but hers?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: No Frank.  No prints.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: He tapes their mouths shut.  We found traces of adhesive around the victims mouths.  We're doing a chemical analysis for components, but it's probably a standard brand you can buy in any hardware store.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: There's only two hardware stores on the whole Island.  We'll check that out. What about the blood?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Not a drop.  Maybe the guy works for the Red Cross.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: This is where he forced his way in.  We found some fibers on the windowsill, probably particles of clothing that rubbed off when he climbed through. I'll know more once I get it under the microscope.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's great.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Wait, I've saved the best for last. Andy, hit the lights, will you?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Same as the others?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: How long she been dead?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: I'd say at least eighteen hours.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That means she was dead before we even finished figuring out the message.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Well what?  I told you this was a stupid idea.  You can't learn anything from someone in a few minutes.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You didn't pick up any vibes from the guy?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I'm a psychologist, Frank... not a psychic.  What's this all about anyway?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What did Dr. Fulton tell you?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Only that you wanted someone from the institute to talk to Sanderson for some case you're working on.  What'd he do?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We're not sure.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: What do you think he did?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We think he could be a suspect in a murder investigation.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I'm busy right now.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's important.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I see you're still having problems with your openings.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: And this Jeremy--

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: --Edmonds.  I know.  You lost to Karpov in '82, didn't you?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No.  I told him to.  I wanted to make sure there was someone on the other end.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: But we heard him.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It could have been a tape.  A prerecorded conversation between Sanderson and himself.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Kathy?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Well, the fact that he views this as a game suggests that he is trying to prove some sense of superiority -- and the way he murders confirms a need to be in complete control of his victim.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: What about the way he arranged the body?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: That would indicate he's playing out a fantasy.  Power-control killers usually fantasize about their actions long before they commit them.  Once they become a reality though, they reach a sense of euphoria and need to repeat the act to sustain it.  But, in all the research I've read on Serial Killers, I've never heard of one moving so fast. It's as if the game is the catalyst for the murders -- not the other way around.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Anything else?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes.  Why disguise your voice if no one knows it?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I was thinking the same thing.  He must be local.  It's logical for him to assume that the police would be there, but he recognized Andy's voice and called him by name.  What about this?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I would think it's some type of clue as to where he's going to kill next?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I don't think it matters.  Last nights victim, Christie Eastman was found in a warehouse on the outskirts of town. The night before, Debi Rutlege was found in the center.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Meaning?
